header.title: THE DEMOTIC MAGICAL PAPYRUS OF LONDON AND LEIDEN

central_thesis: The edited volume provides the first comprehensive, philologically focused edition of the Demotic Magical Papyrus of London and Leiden, a 3rd-century A.D. compilation of Greco-Egyptian magical and medical texts. The papyrus itself serves as a practical grimoire, demonstrating a syncretic magical tradition through its diverse content and linguistic characteristics, notably its extensive Demotic text with Greek and Coptic glosses.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the Demotic Magical Papyrus (Pap. mag. LL.) as a 3rd-century A.D. compilation of magic and medicine. It highlights the text's linguistic importance as the latest Demotic MS, crucial for deciphering Demotic due to numerous Greek glosses, and a source of early Coptic words. The preface clarifies that while it contains Gnostic-like invocation names, the papyrus's content is primarily magic and medicine, not Gnostic systems. It acknowledges previous scholarly contributions and details the editors' approach.

structure_content.chapter_title: INTRODUCTION (I. History of the MS., II. Condition of the MS., III. Contents, IV. Previous work on the MS., V. The Glosses, VI. Date)
structure_content.summary: Details the discovery and acquisition of the papyrus, originally two fragments, by Anastasi and their subsequent division between Leiden and the British Museum. It traces the scholarly efforts to study and publish the fragments, noting the significant role of the Leiden portion's Greek glosses in Demotic decipherment. The section discusses the physical condition, comparing the well-preserved London part with the damaged Leiden part. It re-evaluates the 'Gnostic' label, deeming it a misnomer given the practical magical content. The introduction outlines the papyrus's compiled, heterogeneous nature, its dating to the 3rd century A.D., and the extensive vocabulary including Greek words and lists of plants, animals, and minerals. It also discusses the linguistic characteristics, including the dialect and the nature of hieratic and Greek inclusions.

Provides a detailed outline of the papyrus's practical spells and recipes, categorized into Divination (by vessel, lamp, sun, moon, stars, dreams, or for specific purposes like thief-catching), formulas to obtain favour and respect, various Erotica, Poisons (blinding, soporifics, maddening, slaying), Healing (for poison, stings, dog bites, bone in throat, gout, ear water, ophthalmia, fever, hemorrhage, pregnancy ascertainment), and lists of plants, drugs, and minerals.

Details the conventions used in the translation, such as square brackets for restorations, dots for lacunae, round brackets for added words, and angular brackets for omitted text. It also explains the rendering of the second person singular and the use of '(bis)' for repeated words/phrases.

Outlines the transliteration system for magical names (approximated sounds based on glosses) and citation format for plates in volume II. It includes a section on footnotes providing additional contextual and bibliographical information for the papyrus's scholarly history and interpretation.

The main body of the work, presenting the transliteration and translation of the Demotic Magical Papyrus. The recto contains the primary corpus of magical texts, encompassing elaborate rituals for divination (vessel, lamp, solar, lunar), erotic spells, formulas for various poisons and curses, and healing remedies. The verso contains additional, often shorter, practical notes, medical prescriptions, and invocations, including extensive lists of plants, animals, and minerals used in the magical and medicinal practices.

A table mapping the old column numbers from previous publications (Leemans, Hess) to the new, continuous numbering adopted in this edition, essential for cross-referencing and understanding the consolidation of the papyrus fragments.

key_concepts.term: Demotic Magical Papyrus of London and Leiden (Pap. mag. LL.)
key_concepts.definition: The central text, a compiled collection of magical and medical formulas from the 3rd century A.D., written primarily in Demotic with significant Greek and Coptic glosses. It serves as a crucial document for understanding Greco-Egyptian syncretic magic and Demotic/Coptic linguistics.

The editors dispute the traditional 'Gnostic' label for the papyrus. While the text includes complex invocation names resembling those found in Gnostic writings, its operative content focuses on practical magic and medicine rather than Gnostic theological systems, suggesting common source material or incidental appropriation by the Demotic magician.

The blending of religious and magical elements from different cultures. The papyrus showcases a strong Egyptian mythological foundation (Khons, Amon, Osiris, Isis, Anubis, Horus) intermixed with Hellenistic (Hermes), Syrian, and Jewish (Yaho, Sabaoth, Abrasax) names and concepts, reflecting the multicultural religious landscape of Roman Egypt.

Words, primarily Demotic, with transcriptions in Coptic or Greek characters inserted into the text. These glosses are philologically invaluable for the decipherment of Demotic script and provide early forms and grammatical insights into the Coptic language just as the Greek alphabet was being adopted by Christians.

Detailed instructions for performing magical rituals. The papyrus is noted for describing practical procedures in detail, particularly for divination involving lamps and bowls, which are often merely assumed in other contemporary texts like the Greek Magical Papyri.

A scrying method where a child medium (often 'the boy') gazes into a liquid-filled vessel (cup or bowl) to perceive summoned deities or spirits who then provide answers. Rituals involve specific preparations, purity requirements, offerings, and powerful invocations.

A scrying method utilizing a lamp as the focal point for communication with spirits, often involving a child medium. Preparations include specific types of wicks, oils, and offerings to facilitate the manifestation of gods or spirits and obtain truthful answers.

practical_system.description: The papyrus outlines a comprehensive Greco-Egyptian magical system primarily focused on practical applications, including divination, erotic magic, healing, cursing, and obtaining various favors. It is rooted in a syncretic worldview, combining Egyptian deities (Osiris, Isis, Anubis, Horus, Khons, Ra) with Hellenistic and possibly Jewish-influenced invocation names (Yaho, Sabaoth, Abrasax, numerous voces magicae). The core operative mechanism involves summoning spirits or deities to manifest through child mediums (often referred to as 'the boy') or directly to the practitioner, delivering answers, or enacting magical effects. Ritual efficacy is achieved through strict adherence to procedural purity, specific timing, elaborate invocations, and the precise use of diverse natural substances and ritual implements.
tools: Scrying Vessels: Bronze cups, pottery vessels, new white lamps.
Liquids: Oasis oil, clean water, wine, milk (especially of a black cow), honey, beer, dew of dawn.

Incense/Offerings: Frankincense, myrrh, charcoal (olive-wood), bread, salt, crocodile eggshell, frog's head, bile (crocodile, ass, male goat, gazelle, Alexandrian weasel, cerastes), sulphate of copper, scarabs (live, drowned), ass's dung, ape's dung, ichneumon's dung, smoune-goose dung, kel dung, crocus powder, alum.

Plants and Herbs: Anise, mandragora root, liquorice, hyoscyamus, ivy, apple (seeds/pips), cerastes herb, 'klo' herb, rue, 'shekam' plant, conyza, 'great-of-love' plant, lily, moringa, acacia (pods/fruit), cucumber, wild fennel, 'love-man' plant, 'Great Nile' plant, 'sheisha' leaf, 'fly-bronze' leaf, asphodelos, 'wild onion', 'wild garlic', Euphorbia, pepper, pyrethrum, adarces, native sulphur, sycomore figs, persea fruit, 'asi' plant, 'bel' plant.

Animal Products/Parts: Blood (worm, black dog, ass, tick, wild boar, lizard, camel, night-jar, bat, hoopoe), gall (various animals), heart (hyaena, hare, shrew-mouse), skin (deer, ass), feathers (hoopoe), horn (ram's horn plant described), hair (human, wild she-cat), fish (black Kesh-fish, scarab fish), lizards (two-tailed, hantous, hafleele), shrew-mouse.
Minerals and Stones: Sa-wr stone, ilkh stone, sea-karab-stone, lapis-lazuli, set-stone (Syrian/Ethiopian), stibium (Koptos), natron, galbanum.

Ritual Implements: New bricks (for lamp/vessel support), rush mats (for sleeping), clean linen tunics, girdles, writing tablets, new papyrus rolls, bronze knives, potsherds, kohl-pots, kohl-sticks, rings (gold, for amulets), strips of linen/palm-fibre (for binding amulets), olive-wood table, bay-wood peg, 'pleasure-wood' (ani or ebony wood), vine-wood.
rituals: Vessel Divination (with Medium): The operator prepares a clean space, often a dark cell, and uses a pure child as a medium. The child gazes into a vessel (bronze cup or pottery) filled with clean Oasis oil or water. Specific invocations, combining Egyptian, Greek, and other voces magicae, are recited to summon gods (e.g., Anubis, Thoth, Osiris, Chons) to manifest in the vessel or through the child to provide answers to inquiries. Ritual purity of the child and operator, specific brick arrangements for the vessel, and offerings (frankincense, bread, salt, wine) are critical. The timing can be specific (e.g., lunar phases).

Vessel Divination (Alone): Some methods allow the operator to perform vessel divination without a medium by anointing their eyes with specially prepared ointments, typically involving various plant and animal extracts, along with reciting invocations while gazing into the vessel.

Lamp Divination (with Medium): Similar to vessel divination, but using a lamp as the scrying focal point. The lamp is prepared with clean wicks (linen or sail-cloth) and specific oils (Oasis oil, butter, rose ointment). Invocations are recited to summon spirits to manifest in the lamp's light, communicating through the medium. Techniques involve specific offerings (e.g., crocodile eggshell, frog's head, bile, sulphate of copper, scarab in milk) burned on a brazier to compel spirits or achieve quick enchantment.
Lamp Divination (Alone): The operator may anoint their eyes with a specific ointment and recite invocations while facing a lamp, observing visions and receiving answers directly.

Erotic Magic (Love/Separation Spells): Involves creating potions or salves from a wide array of ingredients, including human body parts (shavings of a violently dead man's head, blood, semen), animal parts (fish, shrew-mouse, swallow, hoopoe, ass, various lizards), and plants (apple seeds, 'great-of-love' plant). These are often mixed with wine, honey, or other liquids and ingested by the target or applied to the operator's phallus. Invocations are used to compel love, passion, or cause separation between individuals.

Healing Spells: Formulas for treating various ailments such as dog bites, scorpion stings, bones in the throat, gout, ear conditions, ophthalmia, fever, and hemorrhage. These typically involve specific invocations to Egyptian deities (e.g., Isis, Anubis, Horus) and the external or internal application of various substances like garlic, salt, rue, honey, specific plants, and animal gall or blood.

Cursing and Harmful Magic: Rituals designed to inflict catalepsy, death, blindness, skin diseases, or madness upon enemies. These often incorporate potent, often chthonic, invocations to deities like Typhon Set, and use gruesome ingredients such as ass's heads, various lizard species, camel's blood, night-jar's blood, hawk parts, shrew-mouse parts, and specific plants, applied topically or ingested by the target.

Protection and Favour Spells: Invocations to acquire praise, honor, avert anger from superiors, or for specific purposes like thief-catching or against shipwreck. These often involve specific amulets, writings on strips of linen, and strong invocations to protective deities or powerful entities.

relevant_quotes.text: THE MS., dating from the third century A.D., which is here edited for the first time in a single whole, has long been known to scholars. Its subject-matter--magic and medicine--is not destitute of interest.

But the papyrus is especially interesting for the language in which it is written. It is probably the latest Egyptian MS. which we possess written in the demotic script, and it presents us with the form of the language as written--almost as spoken--by the pagans at the time when the Greek alphabet was being adopted by the Christians. It must not be forgotten, too, that this is the document which contributed perhaps more than any other to the decipherment of demotic, partly through its numerous Greek glosses.
Hence it has been thought desirable to abandon the epithet 'gnostic,' and to call the work the 'Magical papyrus of London and Leiden' (Pap. mag. LL.).

As has been stated above, the MS. is a compilation. An analysis of the contents will be found on page 14. From this it will be seen to consist mainly of directions for divination processes involving numerous invocations, together with erotica and medical prescriptions, in which, however, magic plays as large a part as medicine.
The vocabulary is very extensive, and includes a number of Greek words, the names of over 100 plants, besides numerous animals and minerals.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Demotic Magical Papyrus of London and Leiden is of paramount relevance to the study of Western Esotericism and Occultism as it represents a key primary source for understanding the practical application of Greco-Egyptian magic in Late Antiquity. It bridges the gap between earlier Egyptian magical traditions and the later grimoire traditions, showing the syncretic development of magical practices under Roman rule. Its detailed operative instructions for scrying (lamp and vessel divination) with child mediums offer invaluable insight into ancient divinatory techniques. Furthermore, its linguistic unique features (Demotic with Greek/Coptic glosses) illuminate the evolution of magical language and the transmission of magical knowledge across cultures, directly informing scholars of historical magic, linguistics, and ancient religions. It provides a rare, direct window into the ritualistic, pharmacological, and theological components of popular magic practiced by non-elite practitioners.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book is primarily aimed at academic researchers in Egyptology, Classics, Ancient History, Religious Studies (especially ancient religions and Gnosticism), and Linguistics (Demotic and Coptic studies). Additionally, it serves as an indispensable resource for scholars and advanced practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, particularly those interested in the historical development of grimoire traditions, ceremonial magic, divination methods, and the syncretic nature of ancient magical systems. Its technical depth makes it suitable for individuals with a foundational understanding of these fields and a capacity for philological engagement.
